Evropska komisija 18-letnikom znova ponuja brezplačne vozovnice
07 Nov 2019, 14:38 by STA

Evropska komisija 18-letnikom, ki si želijo prepotovati Evropo, v okviru pobude DiscoverEU ponuja novih 20.000 brezplačnih vozovnic. Mladi se morajo za vozovnice prijaviti do 28. novembra, staro celino pa bodo lahko raziskovali med 1. aprilom in 31. oktobrom prihodnje leto.



Fotografija je simbolična. Foto: Vir: pixabay.com

BRUSELJ > Evropski komisar za izobraževanje, kulturo, mlade in šport Tibor Navracsics je ob novem pozivu mladim izpostavil, da je pobuda DiscoverEU za mlade v Evropi ustvarila nove priložnosti za odkrivanje celine. "Zelo me veseli, da so se odzvali z navdušenjem ter z vrstniki, sopotniki in drugimi oblikovali povezano skupnost," je dodal. Komisija je namreč v okviru pobude DiscoverEU v treh krogih podelila že 50.000 vozovnic, zanje pa so dobili 275.000 prijav.
Zainteresirani udeleženci se lahko med potovanjem udeležijo številnih organiziranih srečanj in dogodkov ter prejmejo potovalni dnevnik, v katerega lahko beležijo svoje izkušnje. Dejavnosti pobude DiscoverEU so vsako leto organizirane s poudarkom na posebni temi, povezani s prednostnimi nalogami EU. Letošnja je učenje o Evropi, prihodnje leto pa bo tema trajnostna zelena Evropa.
Mladi se lahko za vozovnice prijavijo prek evropskega mladinskega portala do 28. novembra, staro celino pa bodo lahko raziskovali med 1. aprilom in 31. oktobrom prihodnje leto. Kandidati morajo do konca letošnjega leta dopolniti 18 let, imeti državljanstvo EU in biti pripravljeni potovati največ 30 dni med 1. aprilom in 31. oktobrom 2020.
Kandidati in kandidatke bodo o rezultatih izbora obveščeni januarja 2020 na podlagi kviza o splošnem poznavanju EU. Uspešni kandidati bodo lahko potovali sami ali v skupinah največ petih oseb. Praviloma bodo potovali z vlakom, za čim večjo dostopnost vseh predelov celine pa lahko uporabijo tudi druga prevozna sredstva.
Komisija je pobudo DiscoverEU uvedla junija 2018 na predlog Evropskega parlamenta za pripravljalni ukrep. Prvotni proračun pobude je znašal 12 milijonov evrov, proračun za letošnje leto obsega 16 milijonov evrov, proračun za leto 2020 pa naj bi znašal 25 milijonov evrov, so zapisali v Bruslju.

The European Commission again offers free tickets to 18-year-olds
07 Nov 2019, 14:38 by STA

European Commission offers new 20,000 free tickets to 18-year-olds wishing to travel Europe. Young people are required to apply for tickets by 28 November and will be able to explore the old continent between 1 April and 31 October next year.



Photography is symbolic. Photo: Source: pixabay.com

BRUSSELS> Tibor Navracsics, European Commissioner for Education, Culture, Youth and Sport, reiterated his call for young people to discover that the DiscoverEU initiative for Europe's youth has created new opportunities to discover the continent. "I am very pleased that they have responded enthusiastically and formed a connected community with peers, passengers and others," he added. The DiscoverEU Commission has already awarded 50,000 tickets in three rounds, receiving 275,000 applications.
Interested participants can attend many organized meetings and events during the trip and receive a travel diary to record their experiences. The activities of DiscoverEU are organized annually with a focus on a specific theme related to EU priorities. This year is learning about Europe, and next year the theme will be sustainable green Europe.
Young people can apply for tickets through the European Youth Portal until 28 November and will be able to explore the old continent between 1 April and 31 October next year. Applicants must be 18 years old by the end of this year, have EU citizenship and be ready to travel for a maximum of 30 days between 1 April and 31 October 2020.
Candidates will be informed of the results of the selection in January 2020 on the basis of the EU General Knowledge Quiz. Successful applicants will be able to travel alone or in groups of up to five people. As a rule, they will travel by train, and other means of transport may be used to maximize accessibility to all parts of the continent.
The Commission launched the DiscoverEU initiative in June 2018 on a proposal from the European Parliament for a preparatory action. The initiative's initial budget was € 12 million, this year's budget is € 16 million, and the budget for 2020 is expected to be € 25 million, Brussels wrote.
